utterances: Anyway, Matt go ahead.
I'm all here because I'm not all there.
Hello?

Senator Simpson, I'll never forget when you were giving a eulogy, I guess, at Governor Hershler's funeral in the capital and you described him as a man who could tell you to go to hell in such a way that you'd enjoy the trip.
Yep.
And let the record show Ed was a Democrat.
He served with me in the Wyoming legislature.
He was a Democrat governor.
I was a Republican U.S.
senator and he was one of the closest friends I enjoyed.
I was very proud to give the eulogy at his service.
That's what we're talking about here.
Matt, thanks very much for calling up with that recollection.
Let's go to Patrick.
Patrick in St. Joseph.
Is this Michigan or Missouri?
It's Michigan.
Okay.
There's one in each, but go ahead.
Yes sir.
Yeah, I just wanted to comment.
I read a couple of biographies about President Abraham Lincoln and he was known to be quite a storyteller, loved telling jokes.

And one of the one that I thought was really funny was when they used to campaign throughout the country onboard the train, he used to ask Mrs. Lincoln to come out to the back of the train, on that little patio, and he used to say, Come on, Mrs. Lincoln let's go outside and show the folks the long and the short of it.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
That's a new joke you guys used, eh, Robert Reich?
Well, I thought we were the first, and I'm kind of upset, actually, that it turns out that it was used before.
But you know, I think that it's not just physical attributes.
If you go - one common ceremony today is the roast.

And I think that a lot of people who are roastees and roasters kind of - it's a little bit tricky because you want to say something that is both funny and satirical, but you don't want to hurt somebody's feelings.
And I don't know, Alan, whether you've done this, but I've been to some roasts that have just slightly gone over the edge.
I've seen them go all the way over the edge, where the honoree is just smiling with a fixed smile and they can't believe what's going on.
I mean, those were very uncomfortable.
Mm hmm.
They ought to have a trap door beneath, behind that lectern, do you figure?
Yeah.
Oh, boy, I'll tell you, I've been to those.
And people, the ho-ho is just shallow.
It's not there.
I've been to those.
It's hard to roast someone with civility, isn't it, Robert Reich?
I don't think that it's - well, you see...
No, you can do it.
Of course you can do it.
Yeah.
I mean there is a form of humor and there's a form of jesting that has to do with liking somebody.
I mean I kid with Alan Simpson all the time about his bald head and his gangly, ridiculously tall frame.
Don't go into it any further...
And his Wyoming twang and it's all these things that he suffers.
The nasal twang, it's a sickness of my nose, what he's making fun of.
You see, but I can do that because it's done with a spirit of affection and friendship.
On the other hand, I remember I was at some speech and I was making fun of Newt Gingrich.

I was - oh yes, we were talking about the deficit and I said, Newt, you know, I can get by on 800 calories a day, you're, you know, I'm a real deficit reducer and I kind of - I made some jestful remark about his size, and he did not like it.
Hmm.
And I felt, well, that may be because the spirit in which it was understood and given was not one of friendship.
Well, thank you both very much for joining us today to illustrate the fact that a sense of humor and promptness do not necessarily go together.
Alan Simpson, a former Republican senator from the state of Wyoming.
A real treat.
Thank you.
And he was with us here in studio 3A.
Robert Reich with us from the University of California at Berkeley.
And thanks very much for your time today, sir.
Well, thanks very much.
Thank you.
When we come back, who's got your number?
We'll be joined by author Patrick Keefe to talk about the NSA and eavesdropping.
This is NPR News.
And it's a good bet you've never given a thought to this question - when you send a letter overseas, which country gets the money from the stamp?
The country that sells it, right?
In fact, that was a big topic at the Universal Postal Union Congress, which just wrapped up in Istanbul.
Robert Smith from our Planet Money team has been waiting by his mailbox for word on what they decided.
In the old days, it was all so easy.
The U.S.
Postal Service would sell me an international postage stamp, fly my letter to Kathmandu, and then some mail carrier in Nepal would deliver my letter up a mountain.
But the U.S.
would keep all the stamp money for itself.
And the assumption was that if you send out a letter, on average, you get back a letter and it all sort of is a wash.
Jim Campbell consults with shipping companies.
And he says the days of equal mail flows are over.

When everyone looked at the numbers, they found out that big economies, like the U.S., were sending out more mail than they got back - you know, like the J.Crew catalog going to Japan or Victoria's Secret to Brazil.
Or magazines or operating manuals or annual reports or financial statements or all kinds of things.
This disparity was a job for the Universal Postal Union.
It's like the U.N.
for stamps and letters.
The Universal Postal Union decided to create a reimbursement system.
The sending country needs to pay something called terminal dues to the receiving country.
So now if my letter gets hauled up a mountain in Nepal, the U.S.
has to give some of the stamp money to the Nepalese postal service.
But the exact amount of money is being constantly negotiated.
And Campbell says, one of the issues right now is whether or not the U.S.
is getting enough money from other countries.
It looks like the postal service is winding up as a net loser.
Well, I mean that's a very long-term aspiration.
Mm hmmm.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Pope Benedict XVI sat down today with the spiritual leader of the world's orthodox Christians on the second day of his visit to Turkey.
The pope met with the ecumenical patriarch, Bartholomew I, as part of an effort to improve ties between Catholic and orthodox believers.
That effort was supposed to be the focus of Benedict's trip, but after he gave a speech that many Muslims found insulting, the relationship with Islam took center stage.
A key moment will come tomorrow, when the pope tours the Aya Sofia in Istanbul.
The Aya Sofia was built to be a church.
It was then turned into a mosque.

Nowadays, it is a museum, and as NPR's Ivan Watson reports, if Pope Benedict prays or even crosses himself while visiting Aya Sofia, the gesture is likely to further anger both religious and secular Turks.

A week before the pope arrived in Turkey, dozens of members of a Turkish ultra-nationalist political party occupied one of the world's oldest buildings and began performing Muslim prayers under its massive dome.
(Speaking foreign language)
Soon after, they began chanting slogans against the pope.
Police scuffled with the protesters, using pepper spray on them before arresting 39 men.
(Soundbite of political protest)
This was an unusual moment of drama in what is normally one of Istanbul's most popular tourist attractions.
Every day, tour guides walk thousands of tourists through the museum, where they marvel at its massive proportions.
